intro: Galium pseudotriflorum, commonly known as the false tripleflower, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, sprawling stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white to pale pink flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Galium pseudotriflorum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors and stream banks.
